column1: Tullahoma is a city in Coffee and Franklin counties in southern Middle Tennessee. The population was 18
column2: 655 at the 2010 census. In 2019 the population was estimated to be 19
column3: 555. It is the principal city of the Tullahoma micropolitan area (a 2009 estimate placed it at 99
column5: which consists of Coffee
column7: and Moore counties and is the second largest micropolitan area in Tennessee.

column1: Tullahoma was founded in 1852 as a work camp along the new Nashville and Chattanooga Railroad. Its name is derived from the Choctaw language
column2: and means "red rock".

column1: An alternative explanation (see Sam Davis Elliott's Soldier of Tennessee and sources cited therein) of the name is that Peter Decherd
column2: who donated the land for the railroad right-of-way (and was therefore given the right to name two stations along the line)
column3: named one station Decherd
column5: and the other as Tulkahoma (later changed to Tullahoma). Tullahoma was the name of Decherd's favorite horse
column6: which had been named for a Choctaw chief captured by Decherd's grandfather. (There was also a town called Tullahoma in Mississippi
column7: which later changed its name to Grenada.)

column1: The earliest settlement was by farmers from Virginia and North Carolina. Using African Americans slave labor
column2: they developed plantations for tobacco and hemp. Slaves also tended their livestock
column3: both horses and cattle. Early families were named Moore
column5: Anderson

column1: They called a nearby spring Bottle Spring
column2: though it was later known as John Gunn's Spring
column3: since it was on his property. Nowadays
column4: it is called Big Springs. This spring provided water for the steam locomotives. Later it was exploited for health and tourist attractions
column5: as the town developed spa facilities.When the Civil War began in April 1861
column8: was formed in Tullahoma. It joined General Robert E. Lee's Army of Northern Virginia. The division fought in the battles of Bull Run
column13: before surrendering to Union General Ulysses S. Grant at Appomattox.

column2: Tullahoma served in 1863 as the headquarters for the Confederate Army of Tennessee. That year the Union Army undertook the Tullahoma Campaign
column3: defeating Confederate forces and taking control of Middle Tennessee. Federal troops occupied this area for the duration of the war. As a result of the campaign

column1: Tullahoma was little more than a rough frontier outpost
column2: and had no paved streets. 1863 was a wet year
column3: and the place became known to the bedraggled troops of both sides as a place of endless mud. An aide on Confederate General William Hardee's staff is said to have written his own account of the origin of the name: "It is from two Greek words - 'Tulla' meaning mud
column5: ' meaning more mud."The selection of Tullahoma as a headquarters by Confederate General Braxton Bragg has been much criticized by military historians. Although the location was strategic with regard to the road and rail network
column6: it had no strong natural defenses. Bragg did little to fortify it while his forces occupied the area. Eventually the town was evacuated without a battle.

column2: Tullahoma recovered slowly
column3: but began to prosper owing to its railroad link. It became renowned for its educational facilities
column4: a rarity in the area at the time.

column1: At the turn of the 20th century
column2: Tullahoma became a popular health destination
column3: with many spas across town to take advantage of Big Springs.

column1: Manufacturing was developed in the area
column2: notably of shoes
column3: clothing
column5: the General Shoe Corporation was established here
column6: which eventually developed as Genesco. The diversified apparel firm is Tennessee's oldest listed firm on the New York Stock Exchange. Since the early 1900s
column7: a variety of sports products have been manufactured in Tullahoma
column10: and golf clubs by Campbell Mfg

column2: U.S. Route 41A was built through town. This improved access between the town and Nashville
column3: 71 miles (114 km) to the northwest
column5: 77 miles (124 km) to the southeast.

column1: The noted whiskey brand of George Dickel has its roots in Tullahoma. Jack Daniel's whiskey is distilled 12 miles (19 km) southwest of Tullahoma in Lynchburg.

column2: the area benefited from considerable federal investment and development: the projects of the Tennessee Valley Authority constructed dams and related facilities to generate hydroelectric power and electrify many rural areas
column3: as well as providing needed jobs during the Great Depression. Camp Forrest was established during World War II as an infantry training center and later POW camp. The Arnold Engineering Development Complex (AEDC) was the site of early wind tunnel testing by the Air Force and NASA. Later the state established two institutions of higher learning here
column5: and the University of Tennessee Space Institute.

column1: Today manufacturing makes up a smaller part of the Tullahoma economy. The town's growth has been steady though slow since the late 20th century
column2: based on a mixture of education
column3: services
column5: and retail. The presence of AEDC and the Space Institute
column6: combined with a convenient proximity to the aerospace center of Huntsville
column8: has bred a small but thriving aeronautical industry as well. A national aircraft preservation museum
column10: was established on grounds south of the city's municipal airport.Tullahoma celebrated its 150th (sesquicentennial) anniversary on October 4

column1: Rock pioneer Little Richard Penniman died in Tullahoma in 2020.
The Tullahoma Utilities Board (TUB) built a fiber-to-the-premise structure in 2006 and began billing customers in 2009 under its LightTUBe division
column2: which offers television feed
column3: telephone service
column4: and high-speed broadband internet access. In the fall of 2006
column5: the city did a feasibility study
column6: and in December of that year
column7: the TUB board of directors voted to move forward with the project. TUB held open houses and a public hearing to inform residents about its plans.

column1: The TUB board had endorsed the fiber project on a 5–0 vote
column2: but the City Council's approval was needed to secure funding for the project. In April 2007
column3: the council gave the project a green light
column4: and fiber was being installed by December 2007. TUB installed approximately 200 miles of fiber optics. By the summer of 2008
column5: the utility was conducting beta testing with customers
column7: TUB began billing its first customers.

column2: the utility has approximately 3
column3: 500 customers for its LightTUBe system. Soon after it started the TV service
column4: management provided a TV station to produce community events and sports
column5: a thrice-weekly news broadcast

column1: TUB's LightTUBe division began offering gigabit broadband service in 2009. Tullahoma is one of the smallest cities to have a gigabit fiber optic system
column2: and it is one of only a handful of cities in the country to offer high-speed internet.

column1: Tullahoma is located in the southwest corner of Coffee County at 35°22′7″N 86°12′48″W (35.368511
column3: and extends south into Franklin County. It is situated at the edge of the Highland Rim
column4: with flatter topography than in the surrounding area. The region was known as "the Barrens" to the first settlers.

column1: Climate is characterized by relatively high temperatures and evenly distributed precipitation throughout the year. The Köppen Climate Classification subtype for this climate is "Cfa" (Humid Subtropical Climate).

column1: Tullahoma is renowned for its diverse performing arts groups. Tullahoma High School supports instrumental
column2: vocal
column3: theatrical
column4: and visual arts. The THS Band program is recognized for it excellence across the state and country. Their bands have received numerous honors under the direction of Stephen and Marion Coleman and currently
column5: Justin Scott and Lisa Burden. The choral department was developed under Ann S. Baldwin
column6: who started its show choir in 1976
column7: one of the first in the area.

column1: There are many additional venues for the performing arts. The Annual 41A Music Festival hosts local music talent and national artists. The Fine Arts Center displays new artwork monthly from local visual artists. South Jackson Civic Center hosts the South Jackson Civic Association
column2: P.A.C.T. (Performing Arts for Children and Teens)
column3: and Community Playhouse
column4: Inc. All three organizations produce multiple shows annually
column5: ranging from classic plays such as A Christmas Carol to Broadway musicals such as Guys and Dolls and Oliver!
column6: and an annual show production under the direction of Peggy Burton

column1: Tullahoma hosts two state institutions of higher learning
column2: Motlow State Community College and the University of Tennessee Space Institute.

column1: K–12 public education is provided through a city school system.

Tullahoma High School "Wildcat" athletic teams compete in the TSSAA in public school divisions. The Tullahoma Wildcat Football Team is currently in the 4A classification while all other team sports compete in 3A.
The Tullahoma Regional Airport was originally constructed in 1942 for the U. S. Army Air Corps. It features wide heavy duty runways
column2: a large ramp
column3: taxiways and large hangars. Over 100 aircraft are presently based at the airport
column5: 000 transient aircraft visit the airport annually.

column1: The Tullahoma depot continued as a busy passenger train station for the Nashville
column2: Chattanooga & St. Louis Railway into the 1950s. The Dixie Flyer (St. Louis & Chicago - various Florida points
column3: service discontinued
column5: Dixieland (St. Louis & Chicago - various Florida points
column7: 1957) and Georgian (St. Louis & Chicago - Atlanta) all made stops at the station. Service continued after the Louisville and Nashville Railroad absorbed the NCStL in 1957. The Georgian continued to 1968; however
column8: the L&N maintained an unnamed Evansville - Nashville - Atlanta train successor train until April 30
column10: after which Amtrak absorbed L&N passenger operations.
